unit_learning_outcomes.description: Critically analyse Australian politics and assess the ways in which it reinforces, reduces or normalises inequality/
Demonstrate critical understanding of the interplay between discourse, ideology, structures and agency in shaping the makeup of Australian society in terms of race, nation, class and gender
Demonstrate the ability to peer below the surface feature of Australian politics and its discourses to identify the underlying inequalities at play
Demonstrate capacity to assess the extent that the media and new technologies impact – if at all – on the reproduction of existing social relations
Understand and identify linkages between class, race, gender and Australian nationhood

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Reading for class and revision for assessment

enrolment_rules.description: 40cp at 1000 level or above OR (10cp in HIST or MHIS or POL or POIR or MHIX or POIX units)

assessments.description: Quizzes based on reading and lecture content.
Participation in class discussion (either online or tutorials)
Take-home exam - details and timing described on ilearn.
2500 word research essay - details provided on ilearn

relationships.academic_item_name: Contemporary Issues in Australian Politics: Race, Nation, Class and Gender

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Fully online/virtual
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
data.subject_search_title: POIR2010 - Contemporary Issues in Australian Politics: Race, Nation, Class and Gender
data.description: Australia confronts a number of persistent questions: does it live up to its reputation as an egalitarian country whose unofficial motto is a 'fair go for all!'? How have class relations been influenced by the mining boom and its aftermath? Are Australian women and men making progress toward greater equality? What are the prospects for ‘closing the gap’ between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and more recent arrivals? Taking as its central themes, race, nation, class, and gender, the course is structured into sections addressing race and nation; class politics; gender and sexuality.
data.search_title: POIR2010 - Contemporary Issues in Australian Politics: Race, Nation, Class and Gender
